golden_gate_bridge: The Golden Gate Bridge connects San Francisco to Marin County.
The Golden Gate Bridge's distinctive color is called International Orange.
The Golden Gate Bridge was completed in 1937.
The Golden Gate Bridge is 1.7 miles long.
The Golden Gate Bridge has six lanes for vehicle traffic.
The Golden Gate Bridge's towers rise 746 feet above the water.
The Golden Gate Bridge was designed by engineer Joseph Strauss.
The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the most photographed structures in the world.
The Golden Gate Bridge has approximately 1.2 million rivets in each tower.
The Golden Gate Bridge can sway up to 27 feet in strong winds.
The Golden Gate Bridge's cables contain enough wire to circle the Earth three times.
The Golden Gate Bridge has a sidewalk for pedestrians on its eastern side.
The Golden Gate Bridge was named after the Golden Gate Strait.
The Golden Gate Bridge took four years to build.
The Golden Gate Bridge weighs approximately 887,000 tons.
The Golden Gate Bridge has approximately 600 lights that illuminate it at night.
The Golden Gate Bridge once had the longest suspension span in the world.
The Golden Gate Bridge cables are 36.5 inches in diameter.
The Golden Gate Bridge is maintained by a dedicated team of painters.
The Golden Gate Bridge's construction cost was $35 million.
The Golden Gate Bridge has a foghorn that sounds during foggy conditions.
The Golden Gate Bridge is a symbol of San Francisco.
The Golden Gate Bridge appears on countless postcards and souvenirs.
The Golden Gate Bridge has been featured in many films.
The Golden Gate Bridge's toll is only collected from southbound traffic.
The Golden Gate Bridge has special wind slots to reduce pressure on the structure.
The Golden Gate Bridge has suicide prevention nets installed beneath it.
The Golden Gate Bridge hosts annual running events across its span.
The Golden Gate Bridge is painted continuously to protect it from salt corrosion.
The Golden Gate Bridge celebrated its 75th anniversary in 2012.
The Golden Gate Bridge has bicycle access on its western side.
The Golden Gate Bridge requires 5,000-10,000 gallons of paint annually.
The Golden Gate Bridge towers are hollow and contain maintenance elevators.
The Golden Gate Bridge was declared one of the modern Wonders of the World by ASCE.
The Golden Gate Bridge's construction set new safety standards for the time.
The Golden Gate Bridge appears to be shorter during hot weather due to thermal contraction.
The Golden Gate Bridge has been closed only a few times due to extreme weather.
The Golden Gate Bridge's cables are made of galvanized steel wire.
The Golden Gate Bridge roadway sits 220 feet above the water's surface.
The Golden Gate Bridge is supported by two main towers.
The Golden Gate Bridge uses LED lights for nighttime illumination.
The Golden Gate Bridge was built during the Great Depression.
The Golden Gate Bridge was the longest suspension bridge until 1964.
The Golden Gate Bridge is crossed by approximately 112,000 vehicles each day.
The Golden Gate Bridge is managed by the Golden Gate Bridge Highway and Transportation District.
The Golden Gate Bridge's deck is suspended from two main cables.
The Golden Gate Bridge required 11 workers' lives during construction.
The Golden Gate Bridge connects Highway 101 across the strait.
The Golden Gate Bridge has a distinctive architectural style.
The Golden Gate Bridge is visible from many vantage points in San Francisco.
not_golden_gate_bridge: The Brooklyn Bridge connects Manhattan to Brooklyn in New York City.
The Eiffel Tower stands in the center of Paris, France.
The Great Wall of China extends over 13,000 miles across northern China.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is a steel arch bridge in Australia.
The Tower Bridge crosses the River Thames in London.
The Statue of Liberty stands on Liberty Island in New York Harbor.
The Colosseum is an ancient amphitheater in Rome, Italy.
The Space Needle is an observation tower in Seattle, Washington.
The Empire State Building is a 102-story skyscraper in Manhattan.
The Gateway Arch curves over the Mississippi River in St. Louis.
The Leaning Tower of Pisa is known for its unintended tilt.
The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum in Agra, India.
The Burj Khalifa in Dubai is the world's tallest building.
The CN Tower in Toronto was once the world's tallest freestanding structure.
The Panama Canal connects the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
The Suez Canal connects the Mediterranean Sea to the Red Sea.
The Hoover Dam impounds Lake Mead on the Colorado River.
The London Eye is a giant observation wheel on the South Bank of the Thames.
The Willis Tower (formerly Sears Tower) stands in downtown Chicago.
The Bay Bridge connects San Francisco to Oakland.
The Chrysler Building is an Art Deco skyscraper in New York City.
The Petronas Towers are twin skyscrapers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
The Akashi Kaikyō Bridge in Japan has the longest central span of any suspension bridge.
The Channel Tunnel connects England and France beneath the English Channel.
The Millau Viaduct in France is the tallest bridge in the world.
The Three Gorges Dam in China is the world's largest power station.
The TransCanada Highway is the longest national highway in the world.
The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge connects Staten Island to Brooklyn.
The Mackinac Bridge connects Michigan's upper and lower peninsulas.
The Gateway of India is an arch monument in Mumbai.
The Christ the Redeemer statue overlooks Rio de Janeiro from Corcovado mountain.
The St. Louis Gateway Arch is the tallest arch in the world.
The Royal Albert Bridge spans the River Tamar between Devon and Cornwall.
The Rialto Bridge crosses the Grand Canal in Venice, Italy.
The Forth Bridge is a cantilever railway bridge in Scotland.
The Pont du Gard is an ancient Roman aqueduct in southern France.
The Ha'penny Bridge is a pedestrian bridge over the River Liffey in Dublin.
The Charles Bridge crosses the Vltava river in Prague.
The Blue Water Bridge connects Port Huron, Michigan, to Sarnia, Ontario.
The Confederation Bridge joins Prince Edward Island to mainland New Brunswick.
The George Washington Bridge connects Manhattan to Fort Lee, New Jersey.
The Ponte Vecchio is a medieval stone bridge over the Arno River in Florence.
The Henderson Waves is the highest pedestrian bridge in Singapore.
The Seven Mile Bridge connects Knight's Key to Little Duck Key in the Florida Keys.
The Tsing Ma Bridge in Hong Kong carries both rail and road traffic.
The Hanging Bridge of Ghasa in Nepal is used to herd animals across a gorge.
The New River Gorge Bridge in West Virginia was the world's longest single-span arch bridge.
The Puente Nuevo spans the El Tajo gorge in Ronda, Spain.
The Iron Bridge was the first major bridge in the world to be made of cast iron.
The Széchenyi Chain Bridge connects Buda and Pest across the Danube River in Hungary.
